author: 7cc
body:
`Get-Clipboard` just after `Set-Clipboard` sometimes fails to return a value

# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
1..200 | % {
  Set-Clipboard $_
  $i = Get-Clipboard
  if ( $i -eq "" ) {
    echo $_
  }
}
```

# Expected behavior

outputs nothing

```none
```

# Actual behavior

```none
42
48
80
104
131
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: 7cc
doctordns
comments.body: I tried this here too - ran it 100 times - can not replicate.

comments.author: NoMoreFood
comments.body:
I am able to reproduce this under Windows 10 1909 but not nearly as frequently as you.  Also see it under Windows PowerShell 5.1.  I upped your `1..200` to `1..100000` and I see about 25 failures.  Can you try doing the same @doctordns?

Also verified that you can reproduce it under C# / DotNet 4.7.2.  Glancing at the code, it appears that there must be timing struggles related to the clipboard: https://referencesource.microsoft.com/#PresentationCore/Core/CSharp/System/Windows/Clipboard.cs,600

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: It is by-design. The code is thread-sensitive. I do not think that we want to add waiting another thread and delay the Set-Clipboard cmdlet.

title: Get-ClipBoard does not always return a value
